headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: The United States v. Donald J. Trump. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: See you soon, and I'm going to -- to Shan, who brought this earlier to thank me for having him on the show, thanks to Shan and everybody who came on this weekend. Had a lot of the regulars that we have on every weekend, this weekend, and it was -- it meant a lot to me. Thanks so much for tuning in.In the meantime, up next is "THE WHOLE STORY WITH ANDERSON COOPER" unpacking the federal election interference case against former president Donald Trump. Again, thanks to all of you for watching on the weekends. Catch me in the mornings coming very soon right here on CNN. Have a good night, everybody.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.Last week, former President Donald Trump asked the Supreme Court to take up the issue of presidential immunity, further delaying his federal criminal trial related to the 2020 election and the January 6th attack on the Capitol. Now the claim was already heard and rejected by a federal appeals court. It's now up to the highest court to decide to take the case or to let the ruling stand and clear the way for this trial to begin. Now the timing is crucial because the former president is likely to become the Republican nominee. And he wants to delay the trial until after voters head to the polls in November. He's charged with four counts of obstruction and conspiracy. But what exactly is he accused of doing to subvert the election? And is it his actions that matter or his intent? Over the next hour, CNN anchor and chief legal analyst, Laura Coates, will lay out the facts of the federal indictment, most of which are undisputed by the former president and his attorneys, and examine the strengths and the weaknesses of the case against him. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: JACK SMITH, DOJ SPECIAL COUNSEL
utterances.sentences: Today an indictment was unsealed, charging Donald J. Trump with conspiring to defraud the United States, conspiring to disenfranchise voters and conspiring and attempting to obstruct an official proceeding.The attack on our nation's capital on January 6th, 2021, was an unprecedented assault in the seat of American democracy. It was fueled by lies. LAURA COATES, CNN ANCHOR AND CHIEF LEGAL ANALYST (voice-over): In August 2023, less than a year after Attorney General Merrick Garland appointed Jack Smith as special counsel to investigate Donald Trump, the former president was indicted on federal felony charges stemming from his efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election. DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: If you count the legal votes, I easily win. Numerous times we found glitches and every single time that glitch went 100 percent to Biden.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Trump has pleaded not guilty to all charges.MARCUS CHILDRESS, INVESTIGATOR, JANUARY 6TH COMMITTEE: This indictment told a very cohesive story that former President Trump was responsible for the conspiracy to tell American public that the election had been stolen.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Big difference between losing and winning and having it stolen.

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: That he used various mechanisms to push forward that big lie and that had led to the attack on the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Out of the gate, page one of the federal criminal indictment begins with a statement that Donald Trump has spent the past three years denying.HARRY LITMAN, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY: The very first thing they said, Donald Trump lost the election. That's the first statement.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: And even before outlining the criminal charges, the special counsel chose to address Trump's claim that the government has infringed on his First Amendment right to free speech.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The case is a ridiculous case. It's a First Amendment case.

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: A special counsel makes it very clear that the words that former President Trump said he is allowed to say them, but they can be used as evidence to show intent. They can be used in court.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Trump is charged with four felonies emanating from one set of facts established in the criminal indictment.

utterances.speaker: ELIE HONIG, CNN SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: The first one is a conspiracy to defraud the United States, essentially a conspiracy to steal the election from the United States and from the voters. The second and the third charges are obstruction, and conspiracy to commit obstruction, and the gist there is that Donald Trump's goal was to try to block or delay the counting of the electoral votes in Congress. Then the fourth charge is a conspiracy against rights, which specifically means a conspiracy to deprive the American voters of their right to vote because he tried to steal an election that he actually had lost.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We fight, we fight like hell.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: One crime Trump has not been charged with?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We will stop the steal.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Insurrection.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I think Jack Smith wanted to keep his charges as straightforward and plain as possible. I think he realized that insurrection is harder to prove than obstruction or conspiracy. You'd have to approve this intent to overthrow the United States government.

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: Straight to the heart like a cannonball and the heart here is Donald Trump, not the people around him, not the people in the states.COATES (voice-over): Which may explain why the indictment includes six unnamed unindicted co-conspirators from Trump's orbit. Even though the co-conspirators are not named, the descriptors are specific enough to clearly reveal most, if not all, of their identities. There are other reasons why Jack Smith may have declined to pursue indictments against the co-conspirators.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I do think one of the goals that Jack Smith had in charging the case the way he did is to try to flip people.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Others like Tim Parlatore, one of Trump's former attorneys, point to speed.

utterances.speaker: TIM PARLATORE, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Jack Smith clearly wants to get this case tried before the election. There's no way that Jack Smith is going to add a co-defendant to this case because that will definitely push the trial out past the election.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: With this trial time is of the essence. Donald Trump is the leading Republican candidate for the upcoming presidential election in November.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Jack Smith for all the pushing he's done to try this case as quickly as possible, he has never and I believe will never acknowledge that he wants to try Trump specifically before the election. I think he doesn't want that appearance of anything that might be interpreted as being political.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The 45-page indictment alleges in stunning detail exactly what Donald Trump did to remain in power. Much of which the American public is familiar with from the January 6th Committee's investigation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: President Trump relentlessly pursued multiple --ADAM KINZINGER, FORMER JANUARY 6TH COMMITTEE MEMBER: The Department of Justice was able to take what we did and they had some more tools. They had some more ways to compel witnesses, and I think they have a lot more information.

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: Everything we've been learning has been in sort of dribs and drabs and reports with the exception of when Jack Smith file things.

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Special Counsel Jack Smith plans to present evidence.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Filings have tipped the public off to previously unknown aspects of the case, like allegations that a Trump campaign employee sought to start a riot to, quote, "obstruct the vote count in Detroit.Is it safe to say that the indictment is the tip of an iceberg and what they're really preparing to present at trial?

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: I think it is safe to say that the indictment is exactly that, that it gives us a little bit of a vantage point. He wanted to tell a story, but I think at juncture after juncture, Smith has erred on the side of staying sphinx like and not revealing.COATES (voice-over): Which tracks with the special counsel's reputation.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I've never seen a prosecutor who hates the cameras as much as Jack Smith. And I mean that as a compliment. The platonic ideal of the prosecutor would be somebody who has no interest in public profile, who just wants to keep his head down and do the job. I think Jack Smith is that. He's certainly projecting that.

utterances.speaker: RYAN GOODMAN, FORMER SPECIAL COUNSEL, DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
utterances.sentences: Jack Smith by reputation is a hard-driving prosecutor.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Ryan Goodman is a former special counsel at the Department of Defense, and a professor at NYU.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: He has gone after political corruption on both sides of the aisle, Democrats and Republicans. He's also somebody who served as a war crimes prosecutor and has indicted a sitting president in Kosovo. So he's that kind of an individual that moves fast and moves aggressively. At the same time that also might come with some risks.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Why is there some criticism that he overreaches?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Well, if you look at Jack Smith's history, his three highest profile cases before this, all of them have failed, either at the trial level or the appellate level. And so the criticism is while he's overeager, he's over anxious.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: What is going to be one of the toughest hurdles for Jack Smith's team to overcome?

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: Everything in this case will turn on what Donald Trump's state of mind is and whether there was corrupt intent. All the facts they played that on national television. The speeches have been played millions of times.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Here in Georgia, there were tens of thousands of illegal votes cast.

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: So there's not going to be that much in the way of disputed issues of fact, but it's more of an interpretation.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Our election was so corrupt that in the history of this country, we've never seen anything like it.

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: Ultimately the way that this case is going to have to be framed to a jury is the difference between trying to fraudulently overturn the will of the people versus trying to do everything in your power to ensure that the will of the people was accurately counted.

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: It's important to lay out that the former president was told that he had lost the election because it goes back to that intent piece. It's important for the special counsel to establish that former President Trump knew or that are reasonable person would have known that they lost the election.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And we're going to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: It is central because the fact that he knew means that all these things that happened leading up to January 6th and on January 6th had an intended goal, had an intended purpose, had an intended outcome. And that purpose was frankly the overthrow of the federal government and the invalidation of a legitimate election by the people of the United States of America. That's chilling.COATES (voice-over): Coming up.

utterances.speaker: JOHN EASTMAN, FORMER TRUMP LAWYER
utterances.sentences: And the legislature gets to do what it wants.ELENA PARENT (D), GEORGIA STATE SENATE: He had this rogue legal theory.

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER TRUMP PERSONAL LAWYER
utterances.sentences: There's overwhelming proof of fraud.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The pressure campaign hits the swing states.

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: It was a total ambush and I was livid.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: There was a ton of pressure on my colleagues on the Republican side of the aisle to start in motion something that would lead to Donald Trump being able to overturn the election.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: By the time Georgia State Senator Elena Parent attended a meeting at the state capitol on December 3rd, 2020, Joe Biden had already been declared the winner. She wondered why her peers across the aisle had hastily convened this meeting.

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: I feared that we were going to be walking into an amplification of disinformation and conspiracy theories. And the day featured both.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Call the Subcommittee of the Judiciary to order.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Ostensibly the meeting was called to address allegations of fraud in the presidential election. The reality was much darker.Were you expecting to see members of Trump's legal team at that meeting?

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: Not at all. It was a total ambush and I was livid.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The election must be vacated and cannot be allowed to stand.COATES (voice-over): Members of the president's legal team pushed wild, unsubstantiated claims. Some of the most shocking were shown in a video. Trump's team falsely claimed that video was evidence of fraud from election night ballot counting at the State Farm Arena in Atlanta.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Once everyone is gone, coast is clear, they are going to pull ballots out from underneath a table.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't have to be a genius to figure out what happened.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: As the meeting unfolded, Trump tweeted about the hearing, amplifying the lies to his tens of millions of followers. And then another member of the Trump legal team pushed a theory that took the meeting into dangerous new territory.

utterances.speaker: EASTMAN
utterances.sentences: My name is John Eastman. I'm a professor of constitutional law and former dean. PARENTodd about the results of the election, it was our duty to seize the decision on who Georgia's electoral votes should go to. Correct me if I'm wrong here, your argument is that essentially we have a failed election that would require the legislature to step in and assign electors. Am I correct?

utterances.speaker: EASTMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: And that's when the purpose of the meeting became clear.

utterances.speaker: EVAN PEREZ, CNN SENIOR JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: They thought that they could get officials there to call a special session, throw out their electors and appoint a on alternate set of electors or fake electors.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: You're an attorney?

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: What did you make of that legal argument?

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: I thought it was totally bogus because it was very clear under Georgia law that we had no such power.COATES (voice-over): During the hearing, Parent tweeted about being forced to listen to the Trump team's conspiracy theories.

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: All of a sudden, I was going viral in these right-wing segments of Twitter.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: You were being threatened.

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, right away. Right away. Death threats right away.COATES (voice-over): State Senator Parent wasn't alone defending Georgia's free and fair election. Other Georgia officials like Governor Brian Kemp and Attorney General Chris Carr fielded in treaties from the president. Audio from Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger's hourlong phone call with the president was leaked.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: All I want to do is this. I just want to find 11,780 votes, which is one more than we have, because we won the state.GEOFF DUNCAN (R), FORMER GEORGIA LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR: You got to see a window into Donald Trump's heart. He was willing to just push without facts or figures an elected official to do something illegal.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: According to the indictment, Georgia wasn't the only state targeted by Trump and his allies. Across other crucial swing states similar effort to overturn the election were occurring. Time and time again Trump and his cohort were stymied by local politicians, many times fellow Republicans like former Arizona House Speaker Rusty Bowers, who got a call from Trump and Giuliani.RUSTY BOWERS (R), FORMER ARIZONA HOUSE SPEAKER: He said that there is a legal theory or a legal ability in Arizona that you can remove the electors of President Biden and replace them. And I said, I've never heard of any such thing.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Trump also invited Michigan Republicans to the White House where he raised already debunked theories about fraud in their state.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did you make the point to the president that you were not going to do anything that violated Michigan law?MIKE SHIRKEY (R), MAJORITY LEADER, MICHIGAN STATE SENATE: I believe we did. I think that the words that I would have more likely used is we are going to follow the law.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: When it became clear, the pressure on the state and local officials was going to be unsuccessful, Trump and his allies set their sights on a new goal, replacing the Biden electors with those who would vote for Trump.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: At some stage the fake electors plot might have actually been somewhat legitimate.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: While assisting with Trump campaign's legal efforts in Wisconsin. an attorney by the name of Kenneth Chesebro wrote a memo. The memo advocated electors for Trump should meet and cast votes for the then president, while the legitimate electors were doing the same for Biden.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: They wanted to file these documents on the idea that in case Donald Trump were to prevail in litigation then they could submit those certificates to Congress. The problem is that it's switched at a certain point from contingent electors to false electors.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: It was a farce. It was just to keep the image up of the idea that this is being litigated in court and therefore it's legitimate and it was not legitimate. They knew that they weren't going to win.

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: The campaign was central to this effort because you can't pull this off without the apparatus of the political campaign.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Four days before the electors were scheduled to vote, Kenneth Chesebro sent the targeted states a streamlined version of the fake electors memo, instructions and bogus elector certificates he had drafted.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: A lot of these false electors at the state level were duped. They were told that it was contingent on litigation, but they were being lied to.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: To facilitate the voting -- COATES14th, 2020 --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All 16 electors cast their ballots for Joseph R. Biden.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Fake electors met in seven swing states to falsify votes for Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: From the state of Arizona, we hereby certify the following.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: This is an organized effort to do something illegal to change the outcome of reality. If somebody would have produced one ounce of legitimate proof that the election was rigged, all this is -- just going to go melt away in a heartbeat. But they haven't.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Chesebro has since pleaded guilty to one felony in Georgia for his role in the fake elector scheme and is cooperating in another case in Nevada.Up next, the Justice Department under siege.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: At the Department of Justice, civil servants work to follow the law wherever it may lead without prejudice or improper influence. But according to Jack Smith's indictment Donald Trump attempted to wield that influence in an effort to hold onto the presidency.How do you view the level of pressure that Trump placed on the Department of Justice?

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: There's never been anything like it because Donald Trump was so desperate to hold onto power that he didn't care about the rules.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But leadership at the Department of Justice did care about the rules and was not bending to the pressure.

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: Leaders in the Department of Justice told the former president that there was no outcome determinative fraud for them to launch an investigation to overturn the election. So as part of the pressure campaign on the Department of Justice, this is where Mr. Jeffrey Clark kind of rose to prominence.

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: Jeffrey Clark is an environmental lawyer, lower-level person at the department. He was a completely unremarkable figure.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: At a January 6th Committee hearing, former acting attorney general, Jeffrey Rosen, testified about President Trump's call to him on Christmas Eve 2020. KINZINGER

utterances.speaker: JEFFREY ROSEN, FORMER ACTING ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: Yes. It was something about, did I know Jeff Clark or did I know who he was or something like that. I was quizzical as to how does the president even know Mr. Clark.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Rosen confronted Clark, directing him to immediately stop having unauthorized contact with the White House, but the very next morning, Clark spoke on the phone again with Donald Trump. Hours later, Trump phoned Rosen, who eventually asked then acting deputy attorney general, Richard Donoghue, to join the call.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: So during this conversation, did you take handwritten notes directly quoting the president?

utterances.speaker: RICHARD DONOGHUE, FORMER ACTING DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: So let's now put up the notes where you quote the president. "Just say the election was corrupt and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressmen.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: He wanted them to plant a seed.

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: He wanted them to at least leave the door open.COATES (voice-over): They told the president, as long as they were in charge, they would not publicly back his false election fraud claims. So Trump tried to ensure that they were no longer in charge. He began to unveil his plan to appoint a new acting attorney general. "People tell me Jeff Clark is great. I should put him in." The rest of the dangerous scheme would be revealed to Rosen and Donoghue the very next day. In an e-mail sent to them by Trump's alleged co-conspirator for Jeffrey Clark that included this proposed letter.

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: This is a letter that he wanted them to send to the elected officials in Georgia. The idea was to raise questions about the election results in Georgia and suggest to the governor there to call a special session.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: How did Rosen and Donoghue respond to that letter?

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: They were shocked.

utterances.speaker: PARENT
utterances.sentences: It would have been another breaking the dam or another domino falling and the question I have is, what breaking the dam or domino that falls over, which is the one that's going to make the rest of them go?COATES (voice-over): Disturbed by the letter, Donoghue immediately responded to Clark, writing, quote, "This would be a grave step for the department to take and it could have tremendous constitutional, political, and social ramifications for the country."

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: You imagine as a local elected official or a local official getting an official letter from the Department of Justice stressing that there were accusations and frankly evidence of corruption or evidence of votes being stolen. It would lead into an utter panic.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: On New Year's Eve, Trump summoned Rosen, Donoghue, and others to the Oval Office. Again, he raised claims of election fraud. And once again those Justice Department officials told him those claims were false. Trump didn't hide his anger.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: Toward the end of the meeting, the president again was getting very agitated and he said people tell me I should just get rid of both of you. I should just remove you and make a change in leadership, put Jeff Clark in, maybe something will finally get done.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: It wasn't long before Trump did offer Clark the position of attorney general. And that's when Clark tried one more time to get Rosen and Donoghue to sign the draft letter he wanted sent to the Georgia state officials. A letter full of lies.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: So you still refused to sign and send that letter, I take it?

utterances.speaker: ROSEN
utterances.sentences: That's right. I think Mr. Donoghue and I were both very consistent that there was no way we were going to sign that letter.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Undeterred, Clark moved forward with the scheme to keep Trump in office. He accepted the president's offer to become acting attorney general on January 3rd. According to the indictment of Donald Trump later that same afternoon the deputy White House counsel warned Clark that there was no evidence of election fraud, and if Trump remained in office, nonetheless, there would be, quote, "riots in every major city in the United States." To which Clark responded, quote, "Well, that's why there's an Insurrection Act."That evening there was a contentious three-hour meeting with President Trump in the Oval Office. Attendees included White House lawyers, Clark, Donoghue, and Rosen.

utterances.speaker: ROSEN
utterances.sentences: So after some preliminaries the president turned to me and he said, well, one thing we know is you, Rosen, you aren't going to do anything. You don't even agree with the claims of election fraud. And this other guy at least might do something. DONOGHUEpresident should remove Jeff Rosen and replace him with Jeff Clark, and everyone in the room I think understood that that meant that letter would go out.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Then Trump asked.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: Suppose I replace him, Jeff Rosen, with him, Jeff Clark, what would you do? And I said, Mr. President, I will resign immediately. And I said, Mr. President, within 24, 48, 72 hours, you're going to have hundreds and hundreds of resignations of the leadership of your entire Justice Department because of your actions.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: The whole plan here was to put enough doubt in people's minds to give credence to possibly overturning the election. When all of the Department of Justice officials basically threatened to resign, the former president realized that, backed off of that plan, and then turned his attention to January 6th.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Up next.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump lied to gin up his people.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: If you don't fight like hell, you're not going to have a country anymore.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The evidence of the fraud is monumental and more is coming out.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: After weeks of spreading lies that the election was stolen, and creating anger and resentment among his supporters, Trump sent this tweet in December. "Big protest in D.C. on January 6th. Be there. Will be wild."

utterances.speaker: SARAH MATTHEWS, FORMER DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY, TRUMP ADMINISTRATION
utterances.sentences: Now we know there was more meaning behind those words that he used. There was a very meticulous planning that was happening behind the scenes leading up to January 6th.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: John Eastman came up with a really kind of crazy legal theory where he tried to convince the vice president that he had the authority to basically declare which slate of electors is accurate or to not accept the slate of electors. The Constitution is very clear that he doesn't have that authority.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But for Trump, it was the last desperate attempt to stay in the White House.

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: There were multiple steps here. I mean, part of it was to declare that there was fraud and then if you didn't do that to send it back to the states where he felt Republican legislatures would appoint new electors that would then vote for him. If none of that work, he knew that he was going to have supporters coming into town to try to pressure Pence to do one of these things.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But the president began his pressure campaign immediately. Trump tried to coerce Pence on several private phone calls, even on Christmas Day, and then there was the public pressure on Pence.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He's a great guy. Of course if he doesn't come through, I won't like him as much.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: On January 5th, Trump tweeted, "The vice president has the power to reject fraudulently chosen electors." And he released a knowingly false public statement that, "The vice president and I are in total agreement."

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump lied to gin up his people because he knew what Mike Pence was going to do and he wanted them to be surprised and upset because when you're surprised and upset you're much more likely to commit violence, or to do extreme things.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Trump increased his pressure on Pence with tweets starting at 1

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: Based on for years of seeing Mike Pence being very loyal, I think Donald Trump believed that in the end he could get Mike Pence to fold.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We're taking this country back.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: As his supporters gathered for the rally, Trump repeated these dangerous lies.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: All Vice President Pence has to do is send it back to the states to recertify and we become president and you are the happiest people.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: Then Mike Pence puts out his statement that says he does not have the authority to do anything.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The statement came out while the president was on stage urging his supporters to march to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We fight like hell. And if you don't fight like hell, you're not good to have a country anymore.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: He knows that these people were his most loyal followers, that hang on every word of his. And he told them to march to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: After his speech, Trump returned to the White House.

utterances.speaker: PEREZ
utterances.sentences: He was watching the television coverage. He was impressed with how big this crowd was.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: When rioters breached the Capitol Trump's advisers told him to send out a message to calm the crowd. He refused. Sarah Matthews was Trump's deputy press secretary at the time.At what point did you to begin to realize how dangerous this has become?

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: We started seeing those initial interactions between some of the people arriving to the Capitol, and that that was the first sign of, OK, wait, this could really escalate and this could escalate quickly.COATES (voice-over): At 2:24 Trump tweeted, "Mike Pence didn't have the courage to do what should have been done to protect our country."

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: He was putting a target on his own vice president's back.

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: We thought of that as pouring gasoline on the fire, right. We already had a situation that was getting out of control. And the president's tweet just really inflamed it even more.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: We can pinpoint the second that came out and the violence massively accelerated.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: One minute later at 2

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: He did not care about his safety. And the thing that kills me is that the vice president's family was there.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: At one point, the crush of the mob was only 15 feet away from Mike Pence and his small entourage.

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: Hang Mike Pence! Hang Mike Pence!

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: Not only did he just put out that tweet, he also told a witness who testified to us that in fact Donald Trump said, well, maybe he should be hung.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: For more than three hours, Trump refused to tell rioters to leave the Capitol despite repeated pleas from his senior advisers.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: What did he do? Absolutely nothing. He didn't do anything for 187 minutes until he knew he couldn't win.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We had an election that was stolen from us.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The president finally relented at 4hands of these people. We have to have peace. So go home. We love you. You're very special.

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: Former President Trump was responsible for the big lie, was responsible for the conspiracy, which led to the violence on January 6th.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Even in the aftermath of the deadly attack on the Capitol, Trump and his co-conspirators were still trying to convince lawmakers to overturn the election.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: I think that they were using the violence and chaos to their advantage to have more time to make calls to lawmakers and try to get them to go along with their scheme.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Coming up.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: When you look at where we are, I mean, we're standing in front of the White House, the stakes in this trial are enormously consequential.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: The rule of law is at stake. The American democracy is at stake. We have never played at higher stakes than this.COATES (voice-over): And John Dean would know.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: There was a cancer growing on the presidency.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The former White House counsel turned cooperating witness in the Watergate scandal is remembered as the man who brought down former president Richard Nixon. At the time it was arguably the biggest scandal the presidency had ever faced.You said it once that you thought that the darkest days were behind us after the Nixon-Watergate scandal. Is that still true?

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: It is not true. I didn't think we would ever go back to worse than Watergate, but we are there today. We have never been more threatened.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: How strong is this case?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I think this is a good case, a strong case, but not necessarily an overwhelming case. The way these laws are being applied is novel and it's not Jack Smith's fault. It's because we've never seen anything like this.COATES (voice-over): In this trial, most of the facts aren't up for debate.

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: Whenever you're doing any criminal case, intent is always a big part of it. Proving intent is always difficult.

utterances.speaker: DAVID SCHOEN, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: The indictment rises and falls on whether the jury believes that Donald Trump honestly thought there might have been election fraud or some election irregularity. Knowing him as well as I do and in talking to him many times I believed that he firmly believed that there were election irregularities that made a difference in the election.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: What Jack Smith is going to have to show is that Trump knew he lost. The way you have to do that is primarily in this case with testimony from people around him. I think we're going to see a parade of witnesses at this trial taking the stand, saying, I told Donald Trump no unequivocal terms he had lost this election.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Is it going to be difficult to meet this burden of proof?

utterances.speaker: CHILDRESS
utterances.sentences: I never tried a case that wasn't difficult and that's the way our system was meant to be. Taking away somebody's liberty should be hard and that beyond a reasonable doubt is a tough burden to reach.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: What do you think is Trump's strongest defense?

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: I think that a laser-focused defense on he believed that there was fraud.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know, I've had two elections. I won both of them. It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: And that every action he took was based on what he believed his obligations as the chief executive to ensure that the laws are faithfully executed, to ensure that the will of the people was accurately counted. I think that if he keeps a laser-focus on that, that is where the case is winnable at trial.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I think the advice of counsel is an important defense in the case. I can assure you he had many people, lawyers and investigators and otherwise telling him they absolutely could prove that there was election fraud. And I think he was entitled to trust those people whose counsel he chose to trust.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: I don't think that's going to end up working for him.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: Many other lawyers that he would point to are his co- conspirators so if your lawyers are involved in a conspiracy that's not going to work for you as a legal defense.

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: The law is very specific about this. If that's what you want to say, advice of counsel, you need to show everything you learned. That means not just Eastman, but there were lawyer after lawyer within his inner circle who told him there's nothing here. You can't go forward. And all the evidence suggests that Trump just kept going and going and going until he could get the answer he wanted.COATES (voice-over): There has been a sprint by the prosecution to have this trial heard as soon as possible.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I think Jack Smith probably believes that the American public deserves an answer before they go to the ballots and decide who they're voting for.

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: The president can simply command the Department of Justice close down this case. And I don't need to give you a reason.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: So if a trial is going on and Donald Trump is inaugurated, the Department of Justice could simply dismiss the case even in the middle of trial?

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: Not only could they, they would be ordered to. The plug is pulled, all power goes down. It's over.COATES (voice-over): Even if the trial moves forward, Trump can still be found guilty and win reelection. And as president, he may still have one get-out-of-jail-free card.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: He might try to pardon himself. That's never happened before. We don't actually know whether a president can or cannot do that. Pardon power doesn't have any specific limitation.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: What happens if Donald Trump loses and he's convicted?

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: It's a great question and in a way the ultimate question. In theory he's a normal citizen.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Is there a world where an American president can go to prison?

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: There is a world in which that could happen. I think it'd be a horrible, horrible mistake in this country, even if he were convicted.

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: I don't know how they would do it. Every aspect of this case is messy because our system was not built with the anticipation of a president being criminally charged.COATES (voice-over): Which has left a number of legal theories which have never been tested. One major point of contention, the issue of presidential immunity, which Trump is currently appealing.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump's claim here is that he cannot be prosecuted because what he did was within the scope of his job as president.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I firmly believe that President Trump is entitled to immunity. I believe that his conduct with respect to the election was within the official duties of a president. COATESunanimously that Trump is not immune from prosecution for alleged crimes he committed during his presidency to reverse the 2020 election results.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: The argument that Trump is totally immune is absurd. I mean, it is so contrary to American law.

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: And if you can't prosecute a president for crimes, you don't have a fully functioning democracy based on the rule of law.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Trump has taken his appeal directly to the Supreme Court. If the court decides to hear the case, it would first hear oral arguments at a future date and even then, it could be weeks or months before a decision is made.The court could decline to hear the case, which would have the effect of letting the lower court ruling stand and sidestepping a politically charged case at a time when the Supreme Court has been plagued by ethical inquiries and accusations of partisanship.

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: Certainly the chief justice wants in the worst way for the American people not to perceive that the court somehow decided this election. That would be a kind of catastrophe.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: If you were Donald Trump's attorney defending him in this case, what would worry you the most?

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: D.C. jury. The political tenor against Donald Trump is so strong and overwhelming in D.C., in that pocket of the country, that it's very difficult for him to get a fair trial there, especially with all of the publicity.

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: Cases are won and lost at the stage of jury selection because if you don't conduct that carefully to make sure you have a fair and objective jury, you're dead before you even started.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: The goal is to find 12 people who can be fair and neutral. And how many people have no particular view on Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: LITMAN
utterances.sentences: Let's posit for example that a hung jury, that's not a loss, but guess what? In the system with all the buildup we've had, I think it will play as a loss and will occasion real reflection in the DOJ whether to go at it again.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: And all it takes is one juror.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: And I think that's the hope that Trump hangs on to that he at least reaches somebody who ends up sitting in that jury.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Do you think that he will be found guilty in this trial?

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: I shudder if he doesn't get found guilty because I think that sends a message that if you're in power, you can try anything to stay in power.(END VIDEOTAPE)
